title: Wednesday, 11th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hi there

PM11:00am

On time again!

PM11:01am

Stocks are up again!

11:00 am
PM11:01am

We're going to dispense with a pic today

PM11:01am

Too much text to get up

PM11:01am

Sharpish

11:01 am
PM11:01am

We have our own Trump dossier

PM11:01am

Spoiler alert: there's no sex with hookers in it

PM11:01am

PM11:02am

And it doesn't have wave lines of text

PM11:02am

So maybe it's not a dodgy dossier at all

PM11:02am

But let's just print, right

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Cos

PM11:02am

You know

PM11:02am

Public has a right to know what's been said

11:02 am
PM11:03am

This was compiled by operatives still employed By BNY Mellon

PM11:03am

Ahead of Trump's press conference, later today

PM11:03am

We're all on tenter hooks for that

11:03 am
PM11:03am

So here goees

PM11:03am

On January 3 President-elect Donald Trump tweeted: "I will be having a general news conference on JANUARY ELEVENTH in N.Y.C. Thank you" (https://www.facebo...10158408911040725). This will be his first formal press conference since the election in November and is being seen as an early indicator of what he is likely to discuss in his inauguration address on January 20. While investors will certainly be keen to learn more about his infrastructure spending plans ( http://www.vox.com...speech-transcript) and whether he still intends to quit TPP on his first day in office (http://www.bbc.co....s-canada-38059623), a number of other key topics will also remain in focus. This then is what has been said both before and after the election on the issues of USD strength, accusations of Chinese and Japanese currency manipulation, debt and the Federal Reserve.

PM11:04am

"Strong USD"

- August 2015: The FT quoted Mr Trump as having told one interviewer: "It sounds good to say 'we have a strong USD'. But that's about where it stops." (https://www.ft.com...a7bc-ee846770ec15)

- March 30, 2016: In an MSNBC exclusive town hall Mr Trump said: "Do you know, we have a high USD. You take a look at what's happening in this country right now. People aren't coming here, our high USD -- which sounds good to people. Everyone says, oh, that's great. We have a strong USD. We're getting killed worldwide. Manufacturing and even -- you look at tourism and everything else coming into this country, it's not happening. We're getting absolutely outmaneuvered by devaluation." (http://info.msnbc....-by-chris-matthews )

11:04 am
BE11:04am

(@Lemmy: how's everything going in 2011?)

PM11:04am

China & currency manipulation

- November 9, 2015: "The worst of China's sins is not its theft of intellectual property. It is the wanton manipulation of China's currency, robbing Americans of billions of dollars of capital and millions of jobs. Again, special interests and crony capitalism have weakened the resolve of the Obama administration in confronting China over its currency ploys. Economists estimate that the CNY is undervalued anywhere from 15% to 40%. Through manipulation of the CNY the Chinese government has been able to tip the trade balance in their direction by imposing a de facto tariff on all imported goods. Imagine the impact these practices have had on our weakened manufacturing base, our agriculture industry and every small business unable to compete internationally."

- "On day one of a Trump administration, the U.S. Treasury Department will designate China a currency manipulator. This designation will trigger a series of actions that will start the process of imposing countervailing duties on cheap Chinese imports, defending American manufacturing and preserving American jobs. Add to these actions direct and focused protection of intellectual property and we will be back on the path to being the world standard for economic liberty and growth. But these actions alone won't ensure Americans' long-term security and prosperity." ( http://www.wsj.com...lation-1447115601)

- January 15, 2016: "We've lost anywhere between four and seven million jobs because of China. What I said then was, "we have very unfair trade with China. We're going to have a trade deficit of 505 billion USDs this year with China." A lot of that is because they devalue their currency."

- "What I'm saying is this, I'm saying that we do it but if they don't start treating us fairly and stop devaluing and let their currency rise so that our companies can compete and we don't lose all of these millions of jobs that we're losing, I would certainly start taxing goods that come in from China. Who the hell has to lose 505 billion USDs a year?" (http://time.com/41...script-full-text/)

PM11:04am

- May 2, 2016: "We're going to turn it around. And we have the cards, don't forget it. We're like the piggy bank that's being robbed. We have the cards. We have a lot of power with China." (http://edition.cnn...trump-china-rape/)

- October 23, 2016: At the end of October, Donald Trump spoke in Gettysburg, Pa., and released a plan for his first 100 days in office. He promised: "(On the first day of my term of office) I will begin taking the following 7 actions to protect American workers ........ THIRD, I will direct my Secretary of the Treasury to label China a currency manipulator." (http://www.npr.org...is-first-100-days)

- December 4, 2016: President-elect Donald Trump tweeted: "Did China ask us if it was OK to devalue their currency (making it hard for our companies to compete), heavily tax our products going into their country (the US doesn't tax them) or to build a massive military complex in the middle of the South China Sea? I don't think so!" (https://www.bloomb...y-south-china-sea)

- December 9, 2016: President-elect Donald Trump says (at a rally in Baton Rouge, Louisiana): "We'll renegotiate our trade deals, stop the product dumping and the currency manipulation which is a disaster for our country. Every time we get going, China and others, they just knock the hell out of the value of their currency and we have to go back and back, and it just doesn't work, folks." (http://uk.reuters....ncy-idUKKBN13Y2MB)

- December 11, 2016: President-elect Donald Trump told Fox News Sunday: I mean, look, we're being hurt very badly by China with devaluation, with taxing us heavy at the borders when we don't tax them, with building a massive fortress in the middle of the South China Sea, which they shouldn't be doing." (http://time.com/45...mp-fox-interview/)

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Japan & currency manipulation

- January 15, 2016: "Japan, the same thing. They are devaluing - it's so impossible for - you look at Caterpillar Tractor and what's happening with Caterpillar and Kamatsu (ph). Kamatsu (ph) is a tractor company in Japan. Friends of mine are ordering Kamatsu (ph) tractors now because they've de-valued the yen to such an extent that you can't buy a Caterpillar tractor. And we're letting them get away with it and we can't let them get away with it." (http://www.nytimes...-debate.html?_r=0)

PM11:05am

Debt

- May 6, 2016: Mr Trump told CNBC: "I am the king of debt. I love debt. I love playing with it." He noted: "I would borrow knowing that if the economy crashed, you could make a deal. And if the economy was good it was good, so therefore, you can't lose." He also stated: "We owe so much money. Nobody talks about it. Nobody talks about it until the bubble pops and the bubble could pop. And it could pop and it could be ugly. Depending on where interest rates are I think you can buy back [debt]. I'm not talking about with a renegotiation, but you can buy back at discounts. You can do things with discounts." He added: "I have borrowed knowing that you can pay back with discounts. And I've done very well with debt. Now of course, I was swashbuckling and it did well for me and it was good for me and all that. Now we're in a different situation with the country." (https://next.ft.co...bb40-c30e3bfcf63b)

- May 10, 2016: Mr Trump told CNN: "People said I want to go and buy debt and default on debt, and I mean, these people are crazy. This is the United States government. First of all, you never have to default because you print the money, I hate to tell you, OK?" He added: "I said if we can buy back government debt at a discount, in other words, if interest rates go up and we can buy bonds back at a discount -- if we are liquid enough as a country, we should do that. In other words, we can buy back debt at a discount." He also said: "I understand debt better than probably anybody. I know how to deal with debt very well. I love debt -- but you know, debt is tricky and it's dangerous, and you have to be careful and you have to know what you're doing." (http://edition.cnn...al-debt-strategy/)

PM11:05am

- November 20, 2016: David Malpass, the person tasked with overseeing the transition for the Treasury Department and economic policy, told a group of economists and reporters: "So one thing Treasury should be doing, to Trump's point, we should be refinancing the debt into longer maturity. That means as debt comes due, issue longer maturity. And that would protect the taxpayer and be the logical thing to do." ( http://blogs.wsj.c...op-advisers-view/)

- November 30, 2016: Steven Mnuchin, President-elect Donald Trump's pick for Treasury secretary, tolds CNBC: "We'll look at potentially extending maturity of the debt because eventually we're going to have higher interest rates." When asked if he would consider maturities as long as 50 or 100 years, he said: "We'll take a look at everything." ( http://www.cnbc.co...ustained-gdp.html)

11:05 am
PM11:05am

The Federal Reserve

- April 19, 2016: Donald Trump tells Fortune: "I think (Fed Chair Janet Yellen)'s done a serviceable job. I don't want to comment on reappointment, but I would be more inclined to put other people in." He also states: "The best thing we have going for us is that interest rates are so low ... There are lots of good things that could be done that aren't being done, amazingly." He adds: "People think the Fed should be raising interest rates. If rates are 3% or 4% or whatever, you start adding that kind of number to an already reasonably crippled economy in terms of what we produce, that number is a very scary number." ( http://fortune.com...-yellen-fed-debt/)

- November 9, 2016: Judy Shelton, a member of President-elect Donald Trump's advisory team, told the Financial Times that the Federal Reserve has created a "false economy". She reiterated that Mr Trump wants to see someone at the helm of the Fed whose thinking is more in line with his. (https://www.ft.com...8b69-02899e8bd9d1)

- November 22, 2016: According to a report from Bloomberg, citing two transition team sources, Donald Trump plans to fill the two open seats on the Fed's Board of Governors within the first three months of his presidency.( http://uk.business...ointments-2016-11)

- December 5, 2016: Reuters reported that "Fed officials worry there is risk that overly aggressive fiscal, tax and other changes could become inflationary given the economy's current strength. That could force the Fed into more rapid interest rate increases and possibly raise the risk of recession." ( http://fortune.com...rve-donald-trump/)

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 268.80, up 10 (+3.86%), High: 277.10, Low: 267.70, Volume: 13.32m

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Which is still considerable, though the Argos rights issue took a lot of the short interest out. Still about 15% of market cap last I checked.

BE11:15am

Here's Jefferies to summarise where we are.

BE11:16am

JS' Q3 update was ahead in both grocery stores and at Argos. Still, we remain of the view that challenges will be on the increase for both sides of the group, given a combination of sourcing pressures and a more challenged consumer. Valuation considerations (especially 7% FCY) provide a helpful offset to these pitfalls.

Core supermarkets lagging less... with Q3 LFL of +0.1% (JEFe/cons on -0.8%) a clear improvement on -1% in H1. A reduction in food deflation (-0.5% in Q3, was -1% in Q2) was a feature. Market data suggests that more limited loss of customers to Tesco may have helped in the closing stages of 2016. Still, a lack of raise to market estimates today (cons PBT for 16/17 is £575m vs JEFe on £587m) indicates that competitive dynamics remain tough in the core grocery business (at a time of growing input cost headwinds). Impressive gains in clothing and g.m. (+10% and +3%, respectively) mean largely unchanged volumes in the core food business.

...and Argos delivers in the key trading period... with Q3 LFL of 4% (JEFe/cons +2.2%/+1.1%) highlighting good progress given a strong multi-channel offering (helped this year by a maturing Fast Track offering, a key factor behind the 13% growth in online sales). Still, growth appears weighted to lower gross margin categories (technology in particular), and as a result the extension into profit over-delivery is minimal. The group is pleased with progress to date on the Argos integration, with the now 30 Argos digital stores within JS supermarkets performing well. Progress on the Argos front is reassuring, but we remain of the view that overall demand levels will weaken from here, and the effectiveness of Fast Track as an incremental market share driver may reduce.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

...but more headwinds coming through in 2017 a risk. Our 17/18 PBT of £575m compares with consensus of £586m (with a remarkably wide range that spans from £378m to £707m). Such an outcome would represent the fourth consecutive year of earnings declines. And while an already realistically pitched market forecast on Argos' contribution should represent in itself some downward protection (as does FCY still in excess of 7%), we cannot help conclude that forecast risks are weighted to the downside. Grocery gross margin may well prove the greatest pressure point in 2017.

BE11:17am

(@Boncoeur: I'm having a wee bit of an existential crisis about what stock indices are even for. If your UK domestic index could tackle that issue too, that'd be nice thanks.)

PM11:21am

Let me share some Clive Black

PM11:21am

I said some Clive Black

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Split investment thesis; the holistic approach
Our positive investment thesis on Sainsbury's embraces what we deem to be the split nature of the operational performance of the respective divisions plus an appreciation of the valuation and income bearing nature of the equity. We would, of course, be happier if Sainsbury Supermarkets was shooting the lights out and Argos was in a better cycle of profitability. However, reality is that Sainsbury's Supermarkets is fighting for profit stability in an increasingly competitive trading environment and Argos needs to be turned around.

The latter is key to our earnings expectations from the group. In our forecasts we take at face value the expectations that Sainsbury's has set out for the cost of extracting synergy benefits from the integration of Argos and in particular the progressive rationalisation of the fascia’s real estate, incorporating re-locations within Sainsbury stores, and the ongoing broader lowering of operating costs. Should Argos go to plan then we foresee strong medium-term compound earnings growth coming through.

BE11:21am

(I'm pro Sainsbury-Argos, FWIW, which requires being relatively pro Habitat. Not investment advice)

PM11:21am

Of equal significance to us is the potential improvement to the Sainsbury's balance sheet from a successful integration of Argos, noting the aforementioned novel funding of the acquisition outlined above. As such, the key surprise from the analysis of the Argos acquisition to us was the magnitude of the de-leveraging, which makes for a material potential strengthening of solvency ratios in the medium-term, which we feel should filter into the group's equity valuations (we forecast a FY2020 net debt/EBITDA ratio of 0.4x).

Those valuations are also undemanding to our minds, quite consistent in fact with what supermarket stocks have traditionally traded on an earnings and EBITDA basis with more moderate growth trajectories. As such on a FY2018 PER of 11.1 times (x) (FY2017; 13.0x) and an EV/EBITDA ratio of 5.1x, we deem Sainsbury's stock to have attractive valuation credentials. Additionally, the stock has an attractive yield to our minds, 4.5% is forecast for FY2018, covered 2.0x by EPS.

Assuming that Argos integration goes to plan and that Sainsbury's grocery activity remains sound then with de-leveraging, the visibility, sustainability and magnitude of that dividend stream should grow, a prospect that we also like. Accordingly, we expect the market to be concerned about the sales performance of Sainsbury Supermarkets today. However, in the big scheme of things we are content to see a slightly better than anticipated core chain sales outcome and a beat from Argos. Therefore, we reiterate our BUY stance on Sainsbury’s shares.

This is a very solid SBRY trade update. At first glance it may seem below Morrisons (and probably Tesco tomorrow) two explain this: (1) Sainsbury's Q3 is a 15 week quarter (containing Christmas) rather than a shorter Christmas period as reported by Morrisons (9 weeks) and Tesco (6 weeks). Therefore the Christmas bumper sales has less of an impact. (2) Sainsbury's has performed the best of the big-4 over a longer 2 or 3 year period so they don't have the benefit of easy comparatives.

"significant uncertainty" around the deal.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

UBS incoming.

BE11:31am

Downgrade of c8% to guidance, but wording around KC46 more worrying
Cobham issued a profit warning cutting trading profit expectations by 7.5% vs. mid-point of previous guidance range. Cobham expects £245mn of trading profit vs. UBSe £263mn, and against previous guidance of £255-265mn. We believe the main headwinds are still very much related to the short cycle businesses in Communications and Connectivity and Advanced Electronics Solutions. Secondly Cobham announced uncertainty around KC-46 tanker program related to the conformity and qualification phases of its equipment - with no cash payments received from Boeing in 2016. Thirdly, management decided: a) not to pay a dividend in respect of financial year 2016 and b) to place the dividend policy under review.
New management team and Chairman on board
The new CEO had just very recently joined mid-December, the CFO early January. In our view there could be further revisions when the new management fully settles in, and undertakes a deep review of the business. The division decisions, although disappointing, is not a complete surprise. The uncertainty around the KC46 equipment commercial certification remains a concern though.
Dividend cut and dividend policy under review
Considering the higher net debt and weaker trading profit, management decided to cut the dividend and place the dividend policy under review. We note Cobham has a long track record of dividend growth – with 45 consecutive years of increasing dividends as of 2015. We calculate 2016e net debt/EBITA of ~3.3x.
Valuation: trades on 12.3x 2017e EV/EBITA, 14.3e 2017e P/E
Our price target of 160p/sh is DCF based and establishes a fair value '16 EV/EBITA of 13.9x, using 8.9% 5 year EBITA growth (from the low base of 2016e), 85% cash conversion and 9% WACC.

BE11:31am

(@Mouselet: thank you.)

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And Liberum .....

BE11:32am

Year-end net debt/ebitda of c.3x (although lower for bank tests which use average FX). Prior to the announcement the shares were trading on a CY17 EV/EBIT of 13x, a P/E of 14x and DPS yield of 4%. There is a conf call at 8am. Disappointing but many investors will have been waiting for this and recovery should be in sight under new management. We expect disposals will now be in focus.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Stocks going lower as we type

PM11:33am

It's gone thru the October low

BE11:33am

Here's the redoubtable Sandy Morris at Jefferies.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Net debt the issue. The 24 October 2016 Trading Update reported underperformance on trading in 3Q16, but noted management expected an improvement in 4Q16 trading, including QoQ volume growth in SATCOM and Wireless executing "against an encouraging order pipeline". In that context, the seeming £15m EBIT shortfall against our forecast is not a cause for dismay, in our view. We believe the key issue is that the 24 October Trading Update guided end FY16 net debt to be around 2.6x EBITDA, but at the average US$£ rate used for covenant testing purposes. On that basis, our forecast EBITDA of £345m hence pointed to closing net debt of around £900m, but with the risk of a further adverse translation impact when the closing US$£ was applied (we doubted Cobham had the opportunity to implement the planned hedging policy). We estimate the latter at an additional £80-90m. In the event, end FY16 net debt appears to have emerged around £40-50m higher.

The finger points. The shortfall of £20m in EBIT versus the mid point of Cobham's previous guidance suggests - assuming a 40% gross margin - closing inventories may have been around £30m higher than planned. In terms of the balance of £40-50m. A finger may, however, also be pointed at the KC-46 programme, in our view. We believe Cobham may have £100-120m invested in KC-46 working capital. The 24 October 2016 Trading Update identified cash receipts on KC-46 as having been impacted. Cobham remains tight-lipped about the issues it is facing on KC-46, but based on comments in the US Government Accountability Office report on KC-46, we venture the major challenge relates to much stricter than expected certification standards being applied to the AAR equipment fit.

Good riddance 2016. The previous management expressed some faith in Cobham´s ability to generate cash; based on most of the last decade, rightly so, in our view. In setting our FCF forecasts for FY17 and FY18 of £230m and £271m, respectively, we assumed some reduction in capital expenditure and working capital at neutral. In short, the latter broadly assumed no significant recovery from the KC-46 programme. The risk that seems to have emerged is that of there being still further investment in the KC-46 programme. We suppose the argument that Cobham has now absorbed material financial pain - up to and including the passing of the FY16 final dividend - might simply cut no ice with the customer. We make no excuses on Cobham´s part, but will admit to feeling it somewhat tawdry and unsatisfactory and the probable source of significant uncertainty until resolved. In the short-term, we believe Cobham`s valuation will inevitably suffer accordingly.

PM11:37am

Aidan Heavey's appointment as non-executive Chairman reflects the Board's belief that, owing to the unique nature of Tullow's business and relationships across Africa, a phased transition in the leadership of the Group is appropriate. Mr. Heavey's tenure as Chairman will not exceed two years from 26 April 2017 and his appointment is subject to a vote at the AGM. Tullow will be consulting shareholders ahead of the AGM to answer any questions that this succession plan raises.

PM11:37am

I think most businesses claim to have a "unique nature"

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Simon Thompson, Chairman of Tullow Oil plc, commented today,

"The Board and I have long been aware of the need to plan carefully for Aidan's retirement from Tullow as our founder and after 31 years as CEO. After careful consideration of the options, we are confident that this succession plan provides Tullow with the right combination of stability, continuity and fresh-thinking. Paul has been an outstanding member of the Board and has served Tullow with great distinction for 12 years as COO. With Aidan as Chairman, Paul and Tullow will continue to benefit from the founder's years of experience and deep understanding of the relationships that underpin our business in Africa. I would like to thank Ann for her outstanding contribution to the Board over nine years and wish Jeremy well in his new role."

Today’s news of management changes are expected to generate additional volatility - we believe that expectations of a corporate ‘end game’ for Tullow may increase as a result of Aidan Heavey appointment as Chairman for a two-year period - and this could generate additional volatility that follows on from today’s lower-than-anticipated 2017 production guidance.

BE11:41am

Guidance and expectations

Production: 2016A 67,000boe/d v 68,200boe/d forecast (excluding insurance); 2017E budget of 84-92,000boe/d with a best estimate of 88,600boe/d including an insurance contribution of 12,000boe/d.

Revenues: 2016A $1.3bn v $1.4bn forecast.

Net debt: 2016A $4.8bn v $4.9bn forecast.

Capex: 2016A $0.9bn v $1.0bn forecast; 2017E budget of $500m v $450m prediction.

Ghana Production: Jubilee production guidance for 2017 is effectively 102,000b/d; this comprises of output of 68,500b/d (net: 24,300b/d), assuming 12 weeks of shutdown associated with the next phase of remediation works, plus an insurance contribution of ~34,000b/d (gross). Tullow's effective net production is expected to be ~36,300b/d in 2017. TEN guidance has been lowered to 50,000b/d from 65,000b/d, due to some issues with managing pressures in the Enyenra reservoir and because no new wells can be drilled until after the ITLOS ruling later this year.

Drilling activity: Expect a result from Erut-1 shortly; thereafter the rig will focus on appraisal activity before drilling the Etete-1 exploration well. Tullow plans to drill the high-impact Araku prospect (TLW 30%), offshore Suriname, in H2/17.

Other news: Proceedings at ITLOS, with regard to the maritime border dispute between Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire continue, are scheduled to recommence with oral hearings 6-17 February; a final ruling anticipated in Q4/17.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

This report was published on 11 January 2017 at 08:32:02 AM UTC. Maintain Neutral / Raise TP to 280p (from 250p) following the recent departure of the prior covering analyst - we reviewed a number of asset values, and the increase is driven by Ghana (especially our Jubilee valuation) and following the incorporation of today's IMS, which showed a lower than expected ending net debt of $4.8bn (vs CS at $4.9bn) for 2016.

 New CEO appointed. With the successful reset of the business under the leadership of founder CEO Aidan Heavy with the stake sale of Uganda being the last bit of the jigsaw, the company announced the decision to appoint Paul McDade, current COO of TLW, to be the next CEO of the company. The energy sector in particular is a relationship business, especially so across Africa, where Paul has been effectively running the business for TLW in Ghana, Uganda and Kenya. Aidan will stay on as Chairman for up to two years to ensure an effective transition. Other updates worth highlighting from today's release include (a) slightly lower production guidance for TEN in 2017 (now expecting gross 50kbd), albeit this was previously flagged, but not yet quantified, and (b) capex of $0.5bn in 2017, albeit it is likely to be less than $0.4bn once the transaction with Total in Uganda is completed.

 Investment Overview: After years of heavy investment, TLW has reached an inflection point in its cash cycle as the ramp-up of production from TEN should allow the company to slowly deleverage - generating free cash flow at less than $50/bbl in 2017. Its flagship asset, Jubilee, produced below capacity in early 2016 due to issues with the FPSO, and a timetable for permanent repairs has been established. TLW has insurance to cover both the cost of repairs and revenues from lost production at Jubilee. TLW announced an agreement to farm-down a stake in Uganda to Total further de-risking balance sheet concerns - it should de-gear fast from hereon at our macro.

 Catalysts and Risks: TLW has commenced the next phase of its Kenyan exploration program in December, in an effort to grow the resource base towards 1bnbbls gross (from 750mmbbls), which we think is necessary to attract partners to fund the export pipeline for commercial production.

 Valuation: We set our TP in line with our DCF based risked NAV, which uses a long-term $65/bbl Brent oil price assumption.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: As expected, sales volumes remain subdued, with Q4 sales revenues of cú12m vs.
ú20m in FY15, whilst lettings remained stable at cú13m, flat y-o-y. Foxtons has opened
seven new branches in 2016. A further two branches are committed for Q1 2017, but
we would expect a pull-back in new openings otherwise.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Foxtons is guiding to volumes in 2017 below 2016, reflecting the annualising of
current market conditions after a strong Q1 2016. We forecast London volumes down
10% in FY17, but expect margins to be supported by cost actions (annualised cost
savings of ú6m already made), and a slowdown in new openings.

Peel Hunt too, for the longer take.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Foxtons’ update highlights that conditions in the London
residential market remain challenging, particularly in sales. Fullyear 2016 EBITDA is expected to be c46% lower than the prior
year at £25m and c10% below consensus. There has been no
improvement in trading through the second half and the outlook
for 2017 is tough, with market volumes expected to be down on
2016 levels. The shares are trading on 14.9x our 2017 forecasts.
We maintain our Sell recommendation and 80p target price.

BE11:49am

Trading update. Full-year revenues of £133m were 11% down on the prior year,
with EBITDA of £25m c46% below 2015 levels and c10% lower than consensus.
The EBITDA margin of 18.7% compares to 30.7% in the prior year, highlighting
the high operational gearing in the business, which was amplified by the opening
of seven new branches in the year against a weaker market. The balance sheet
remains in decent shape and was debt free at the year end.
Sales and lettings. Full-year sales revenues were down by c24% to c£56m, with
a weakening trend through the second half. Letting revenues were broadly flat at
c£68m and while there was a good level of renewals, the typically higher margin
new tenant business was lower, with pressure on rents too. The proposed ban on
letting fees by the Government could lead to further pressure on profits (we
estimate c£3m for Foxtons), with a consultation due to start with the industry in
the coming months.
Outlook. The group is facing tough comparatives in Q1 as the surge in activity in
early 2016 ahead of stamp duty changes will not be repeated. Overall market
volumes are expected to be lower in 2017 (we estimate c5%) and we continue to
believe that the group’s market share progress will be stymied by its high
commission rates.
Forecasts and valuation. The business has made some cost cuts (c£3m), the full
benefits of which will come through in 2017. We have incorporated this into our
forecasts, but still expect little or no progress on profitability. We leave our
forecasts unchanged at this stage and with the shares trading on a 2017E PE of
14.9x, we see further downside risks. We maintain our Sell recommendation and
80p target price.

BE11:52am

Double upgrade to BUY with 2600p price objective We are double upgrading our rating on Spectris from Underperform to BUY with a price objective of 2600p (12.5x 2018E EV/EBITA). Our cautious view on Spectris in recent years has centred on the group’s inability to materially cut costs and offset inflationary pressures in a low-growth world. This looks set to change as Spectris launches ‘Project Uplift’ with the aim of significantly reducing its cost base and increasing efficiencies.

We also think process industry end markets can turn more positive in 2017 and that Spectris should start to see growth after several years of decline. With growth inflecting and restructuring to gain pace, we think margins should increase during 2017 and 2018.

‘Project Uplift’ to ensure cost efficiency Spectris has high gross margins but also a large overhead (SG&A) base to serve its 14 operating divisions. In the past, we argued it was not managing this SG&A productively, especially in the face of volume declines and the result was deteriorating margins.

BE11:53am

In 2017, the Group will start implementing Project Uplift, a group wide efficiency programme focusing on G&A cost, HR management, IT and indirect purchasing. No details have yet been given but we would expect an update on expected savings and cost of implementation at FY16 results in February. For 2016, Spectris should deliver £10m in savings, but the scope of Project Uplift should double/treble this or more. For 2017, we expect a break-even effect after charges but more significant benefits in 2018.

Upgrade estimates c.4-9%; well ahead of consensus We have upgraded our 2017 and 2018 estimates by c.4-9% respectively on the basis of cost savings derived from Project Uplift. Our profit estimates (EBITA and EPS) look to be 8-12% ahead of consensus (Factset). We estimate Spectris trades at a c2-.5% discount to the sector on EV/EBITA and PE metrics but take the view that it should trade on a modest premium, given (i) the scope for cyclical recovery implying growth at least equal to the sector average (ii) potential step change in cost restructuring.

BE11:55am

We upgrade Burberry to OW and raise our PT to 1760p based on 19.6x 2018E PE, in
line with the sector. We believe the company offers good value at a 15% discount to
the luxury sector, which we see as unjustified given its well laid-out strategy to
drive store density in the medium term. Shorter-term the group should benefit from
its cost-reduction programme, which the company expects to save at least £100m.

With the new CFO/COO arriving in January and new CEO by the summer, we believe
the company will generate positive momentum in 2017. The group reports Q3 retail
sales on 18 January – although we do not believe this is a catalyst given the medium
to long-term benefits of the strategy. However, the current brand heat on WeChat in
China following its tie-up with Kris Wu augers well, and with the Chinese consumer
accounting for 40% global retail sales, we believe the medium-term outlook is
positive. While current FX rates suggest a £10m headwind since the Q2 results, the
group should benefit from a £40m tailwind in 2018E.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

(sorry about the lumpy formatting.)

BE11:56am

Good potential from medium-term strategy: Product focus will be led by bags (c20%
sales) with a new category manager helping to develop growth in key shapes and
styles. Retail is the main area to improve given low densities compared to peers. This will
be boosted by staff incentivisation, better merchandising under ‘one Burberry’ and an
expansion of its VIP programme. Shorter-term its cost reduction of at least £100m by
2019 offers upside, helped by FX tailwinds that we estimate at £115m in 2017 and
£40m in 2018. The new CFO/COO Julie Brown joins this month with Marco Gobbetti
(CEO) in the summer and we expect both will support and enhance the new strategy.
Social media: The Chinese festival campaign with Kris Wu in China helped elevate
brand heat in the region, with Wechat likes up 10 times in November. The sales impact
of this is difficult to quantify but it demonstrates that its well lauded digital approach, a
key pillar of the long-term strategy, continues to create heat and excitement.

We assume +2% like-for-like in Q3’16 against a flat comp and after -4% in Q1 17 (Q1
16 +6%) and +2% in Q2 17 (Q2 16 -4%). This implies a robust quarter that we believe is
justified given the exposure to UK (c10% sales), China c10%, Korea c8% and Asia ex HK
generally. The weather has also been more conducive to trench coat and outerwear sales
this year. With 2% new space and 21% FX, we estimate Q3 sales of £752m – up 25%.
